questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for generalized fatigue and mild shortness of breath on exertion for 3 months. He has a history of recurrent patellar dislocations. He is at the 99th percentile for height and at the 30th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 140/50 mm Hg. Examination shows scoliosis, a protruding breast bone, thin extremities, and flat feet. Ocular examination shows bilateral upward displacement of the lenses. A grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 is the pathological closure of the pulmonic valve before the aortic valve. Instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 with inspiration, S2 will instead split with expiration. Conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block, may cause paradoxical splitting of S2. However, AR is unlikely to be the sole cause of a paradoxical splitting of S2.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is not associated with AR. Instead, it is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or tension pneumothorax, and is sometimes observed in asthma and pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is a delayed pulse with a low amplitude that is not associated with AR. Instead, it is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, who typically present with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur and, in more severe aortic stenosis, with angina, syncope, or heart failure.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 is not associated with AR; it is most commonly a result of an atrial septal defect. The second heart sound arises from the sequential closing of the aortic valve and the pulmonic valve. Inspiration increases right ventricular preload, resulting in a delay in pulmonary valve closure, which produces a physiological splitting of S2. Atrial septal defects produce a left-to-right shunt, increasing right atrial and right ventricular volume and forcing the pulmonic valve to close later regardless of breath.
Image Description:

A fixed split does not change with respiration and tends to be wide (i.e., the split is also audible during expiration). It may occur in atrial septal defect or severe right ventricular failure.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

E) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with AR. On palpation of a peripheral artery, such as the radial artery, the clinician will feel rapid engorgement of the artery followed by a significant, prompt collapse of the vessel. This is due to the incompetent aortic valve failing to maintain adequate diastolic pressure in the arterial system, which also causes a widened pulse pressure. Other findings of AR include pulse synchronous head nodding (de Musset's sign) and, occasionally, a rumbling, low-pitched mid-diastolic murmur (Austin Flint murmur) that is caused by the regurgitant blood striking the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, leading to premature closure of the mitral leaflets.

Patients with Marfan syndrome often have aortic disease (e.g., aortic regurgitation) as a consequence of cystic medial degeneration.

F) INCORRECT:

Radio-femoral pulse delay is caused by aortic coarctation. Physiologically, pulses rise simultaneously in the radial and femoral arteries. However, due to the restricted blood flow through the narrowed aorta, the femoral pulse will rise later than the radial pulse. AR does not cause radio-femoral pulse delay.
questions.hint: This teenager with tall stature, scoliosis, pectus deformity, thin extremities, and upward displacement of the lenses likely has Marfan syndrome. The presence of an early diastolic murmur and widened pulse pressure indicate aortic regurgitation (AR).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child examination. The boy was born at term via vaginal delivery and has been healthy except for severe myopia. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Oral examination shows a high-arched palate. He has unusually long, slender fingers and toes, and his finger joints are hyperflexible. The patient is asked to place his thumbs in the palms of the same hand and then clench to form a fist. The thumbs are noted to protrude beyond the ulnar border of the hand. Slit-lamp examination shows lens subluxation in the superotemporal direction bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with severe myopia, tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, positive thumb sign, and superotemporal lens subluxation, which together strongly suggest Marfan syndrome (MFS). A mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene causes MFS. Fibrillin-1 is needed to form microfibrils that provide strength to connective tissue and store growth factors. A mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene thus leads to defective connective tissue (causing hypermobility and lens dislocation) and excessive growth factor release (causing tall stature).

While there is no cure for MFS, preliminary data suggest that ARBs (e.g., losartan) may have a protective or even reversing effect in some of the clinical manifestations of MFS. Other treatment options focus on preventing specific symptoms (e.g., aortic dilatation treated with beta blockers, and scoliosis treated with bracing, physical therapy, and analgesia).

B) INCORRECT:

Defects in homocysteine metabolism (e.g., cystathionine synthase deficiency) cause homocystinuria, which presents with tall stature, arachnodactyly, and/or lens subluxation. However, subluxation of the ocular lens in homocystinuria is typically inferior and nasal and not superior and temporal as seen in this patient. Other typical features of homocystinuria include intellectual disability and increased risk of thromboembolic episodes, for which there are no indications in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective collagen cross-linking causes Ehler-Danlos syndrome type VI (EDS VI), which can cause joint hypermobility. However, EDS does not result in lens subluxation.

D) INCORRECT:

Nondisjunction of the sex chromosomes can cause Klinefelter syndrome, which presents with tall, slim stature because of delayed growth plate closure due to testosterone deficiency. However, it is not associated with myopia, lens subluxation, or joint hypermobility.

E) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the fragile X mental retardation 1 gene (FMR1 gene) causes fragile X syndrome, which can present with tall stature and hypermobile joints. However, other typical craniofacial features include a long and narrow face, large ears, and relative macrocephaly, which this patient lacks. Moreover, it does not cause lens subluxation.

F) INCORRECT:

A point mutation in the RET gene can cause multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and 2B (MEN 2A and MEN 2B). Individuals with MEN 2B classically present with tall stature and joint hypermobility, as seen in this patient, but other typical findings, such as multiple neuromas, pheochromocytoma, and medullary thyroid carcinoma are absent. Moreover, multiple endocrine neoplasia does not cause lens subluxation. MEN 2A can manifest with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism.
questions.hint: Other features associated with this patient's condition include aortic conditions, pectus deformity, and skin hyperextensibility.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-hour history of left shoulder pain and inability to move the shoulder. He began taking swimming classes a couple of weeks ago and he has been complaining of shoulder pain during those classes. He often has to stop swimming and interrupt the class. His parents report that he has been healthy except for the fact that he bruises easily and sometimes does not eat because of pain while chewing. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows the left upper extremity externally rotated and slightly abducted. Palpation of the left shoulder joint shows tenderness and an empty glenoid fossa. The left humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. The right upper extremity is unremarkable. The skin can be stretched further than normal and is fragile. There are widened atrophic scars on his knees. There is tenderness to palpation of the temporomandibular joints bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired copper absorption occurs in individuals with Menkes disease. Affected children present at 2–3 months of age with abnormal facial features, brittle hair, pronounced truncal hypotonia, and connective tissue abnormalities (e.g., osteoporosis). Over the course of the disease, children also develop epilepsy, fail to thrive, and do not meet developmental milestones. This patient, however, does not present with any of these findings; skin hyperextensibility and fragility, large joint dislocation, and temporomandibular tenderness suggest a different connective tissue disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective type III procollagen formation is the cause of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS). Although vascular EDS can also manifest with easy bruising, atrophic scars, and skin hyperextensibility, small rather than large joint hypermobility is expected in patients with vascular EDS; large joint dislocation is not expected. Moreover, patients with this rare and severe type of EDS often present with thin and translucent skin, varicosis, and characteristic facial features (thin face, lips, and nose; prominent eyes, lobeless ears).

C) CORRECT:

Defective type V collagen is the cause of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type II (classic EDS), which is characterized by connective tissue fragility that predominantly affects the joints and skin. Typical clinical features include joint hypermobility and subluxation/dislocation (e.g., patella, temporomandibular, shoulder), skin hyperextensibility and fragility, and skeletal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis). The fragile skin tends to bruise and break easily, leading to potentially severe lacerations from minor trauma. Abnormal wound healing results in atrophic scars. Cardiovascular features are seen less commonly in classic EDS but may include heart valve defects and aneurysms/dissections of large arteries.
Image Description:

The skin of the elbow is hyperelastic (cutis hyperelastica) due to impaired collagen synthesis.

This, along with joint hypermobility, is a characteristic feature of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

A mutation of the fibrillin-1 gene causes Marfan syndrome, which also manifests with large joint dislocations and skin hyperextensibility. However, patients with Marfan syndrome typically have tall stature, long extremities, and arachnodactyly, all of which are absent here. Other features of Marfan include vascular abnormalities (e.g., aortic aneurysm or dissection, berry aneurysms), eye abnormalities (e.g., lens dislocation), and pectus abnormalities (e.g., pectus carinatum).

E) INCORRECT:

Defective type I collagen is the cause of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which can also manifest with easy bruising and joint hypermobility. However, hyperextensible skin is not characteristic. Moreover, patients with OI typically have brittle bones, bowing of bones and saber shins, recurrent fractures following minor trauma, growth retardation, and blue sclerae, all of which are absent here.
Image Description:

The sclerae show a distinct blue-grey tint.
questions.hint: Shoulder pain together with external rotation of the shoulder with slight abduction and palpation of the left humeral head below the coracoid process indicates anterior shoulder dislocation. Multiple episodes of shoulder pain during swimming classes are suggestive of shoulder subluxations.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child examination. He has been healthy and has met all developmental milestones. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Auscultation of the heart shows a high-frequency, midsystolic click that is best heard at the fifth left intercostal space. Oral examination shows a high-arched palate. He has atypically long, slender fingers and toes. The patient is asked to clasp the wrist of the opposite hand and the little finger and thumb overlap. Slit-lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molecular genetic testing is indicated to rule out fragile X syndrome, which also presents with tall stature, hypermobile joints, and features of MVP. However, the absence of other key features like intellectual disability, delayed language development, long facies, large ears, and macroorchidism make the diagnosis unlikely. Although genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome, the condition is a clinical diagnosis and any form of molecular/genetic testing is not indicated in a patient with classic features, as is the case here. Considering the clinical presentation, a different diagnostic procedure is more important in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping is indicated if an underlying chromosomal disorder is suspected. This patient has MVP and is at the 97th percentile for height, which could be suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome. However, the rest of the physical examination findings (e.g., lens subluxation, joint hypermobility, arachnodactyly) cannot be explained by Klinefelter syndrome. For this reason, karyotyping would not be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Echocardiography is indicated in patients with suspected Marfan syndrome to evaluate for cardiac or aortic disease (e.g., aortic root dilatation, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection). These findings, if present, support the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome and are potentially fatal if left untreated. A midsystolic click at the cardiac apex is highly suggestive of MVP, which is commonly associated with connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Treatment of MVP in asymptomatic patients is unnecessary.

Slit-lamp examination is the second most important diagnostic test in children diagnosed with Marfan syndrome. As in this patient case, it can reveal commonly associated ocular abnormalities (e.g., superotemporal lens dislocation, retinal detachment).

D) INCORRECT:

A thyroid biopsy is indicated for suspected thyroid cancer. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia 2B (MEN 2B). This condition is often characterized by marfanoid body habitus (i.e., increased height, elongated limbs, and joint hypermobility), which is seen in this patient. However, the complete absence of any mucosal neuromas, which are generally the first clinical manifestation of MEN 2B, or any features of medullary thyroid cancer (e.g., thyroid nodule) or pheochromocytoma (e.g., hypertension, diaphoresis, tachycardia) makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) develops in almost all patients with MEN 2. Therefore, if there is clinical suspicion for MEN 2 (i.e., at least two typical clinical findings), genetic testing should be performed, followed by measurement of the serum calcitonin and thyroid ultrasound to screen for MTC.

E) INCORRECT:

IGF-1 measurement may be indicated in a child with tall stature to detect excess growth hormone, which indicates gigantism. However, patients with gigantism usually exhibit much more rapid growth than this child. Moreover, gigantism is associated with other characteristics, such as coarse facial features, thickening of the fingers and toes, headaches, and visual changes (mass effect due to pituitary adenoma), and macrocephaly, which are all absent in this patient. IGF-1 measurement is therefore not indicated in this patient.

Acromegaly refers to abnormally high linear growth due to excessive IGF-I production after the growth plate cartilages have fused in adulthood. If the condition occurs before epiphyseal plate closure, it is referred to as gigantism.

F) INCORRECT:

An elevated plasma homocysteine concentration is diagnostic of homocystinuria. This condition typically manifests with a marfanoid body habitus (i.e., tall stature, long extremities, and arachnodactyly) and subluxation of the ocular lens, as seen in this child. However, the absence of thrombotic events (e.g., stroke), developmental delay, and intellectual disability make Marfan syndrome the more likely diagnosis. Furthermore, lens subluxation in homocystinuria usually occurs in a downward direction rather than superolaterally.
questions.hint: The combination of tall stature, a high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, a positive wrist sign, mitral valve prolapse (MVP), and lens subluxation (ectopia lentis) in the superotemporal direction strongly suggests Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female college student comes to the physician for a sudden loss of visual acuity of her right eye. She noticed that she was unable to read the time on the alarm clock when she woke up in the morning. When she closes her right eye, she is able to see sharply. When she closes her left eye, she has blurry double vision. She does not recall trauma to her eye but has been working long nights on her honors thesis. She has a history of occasional shoulder luxation. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall, and weighs 62 kg (136 lbs); her BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, slender and long fingers are noted. She has several flat, demarcated brownish nevi on her left cheek. Ocular examination shows upward temporal subluxation of her right lens. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Joint hypermobility syndrome is often connected with a tendency of the joints to dislocate, as seen in this patient. However, there are no ocular complications in joint hypermobility syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Homocystinuria often has a similar clinical presentation to Marfanoid habitus and lens subluxation. However, lens subluxation is typically downward and inward in a patient with homocystinuria, as opposed to the upward and outward direction found in this woman. Additionally, patients with homocystinuria usually have an intellectual disability, megaloblastic anemia, and thromboembolic events or premature atherosclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2B (MEN2B) often causes a marfanoid habitus with ocular complications, as seen in this patient. However, the ocular complications are due to neuromas and do not involve the lens. Additionally, this patient does not have any signs of other complications of MEN2B, such as pheochromocytoma, oral mucosal neuromas, or thyroid cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Sturge-Weber syndrome may present with ocular complications, the most common being early-onset glaucoma, not lens subluxation. Additionally, characteristic dermatologic findings include a “port-wine stain” as opposed to the junctional nevi seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Although Ehlers-Danlos syndrome also manifests with joint laxity and arachnodactyly, this woman's disproportionately tall stature and ocular findings suggest another diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Marfan syndrome may result in superotemporal lens subluxation due to incompetent zonular fibers and structural abnormalities of the lens capsule. The upward and temporal direction is a relatively specific finding that can help distinguish Marfan syndrome from other causes of lens subluxation. Additionally, her clinical picture (tall stature, arachnodactyly, and recurrent shoulder luxation) is typical for patients with this condition. This patient requires a thorough cardiac examination, as patients with Marfan syndrome often have cardiovascular complications (e.g., aortic regurgitation and/or aortic dissection).

The skin lesions on her left cheek are most likely common acquired melanocytic nevi, which are not relevant for the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.
questions.hint: This tall woman presents with lens subluxation, arachnodactyly, and joint hypermobility which raises suspicion for a hereditary connective tissue disorder.

questions.text: A 25-year old man comes to the physician because of fatigue over the past 6 months. He has been to the emergency room several times over the past 3 years for recurrent shoulder and patella dislocations. Physical examination shows abnormal joint hypermobility and skin hyperextensibility. A high-frequency mid-systolic click is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is most likely to result in an earlier onset of this patient’s auscultation finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased afterload and subsequent increased left ventricular end-systolic volume during hand grip (hand clenching) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

B) CORRECT:

The characteristic auscultatory finding of MVP is a high-frequency mid-systolic click, which is caused by sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae as the valve leaflets prolapse. The click may be followed by a mid-to-late systolic murmur indicating mitral regurgitation. Since the prolapse occurs when the contracting ventricle reaches a critical volume, the timing of the click varies according to the left ventricular end-diastolic volume (EDV). Decreased EDV, e.g., due to decreased venous return to the heart during abrupt standing (i.e., decreased preload) causes the leaflets to prolapse sooner, resulting in an earlier onset (i.e., closer to S1) and increased intensity of auscultatory findings. Conversely, maneuvers that increase the volume (e.g., squatting) result in a later onset and decreased intensity.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased venous return to the heart during rapid squatting (i.e., increased preload) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

D) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased venous return to the heart during the release phase of the Valsalva maneuver (i.e., increased preload) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Leaning forward brings the heart closer to the chest, but it has no significant impact on preload or afterload, so it does not affect the timing of the murmur of mitral valve prolapse. However, a pericardial friction rub and the murmur of aortic regurgitation are best heard with the patient leaning forward.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which can manifest with joint hypermobility (predisposing to joint dislocations) and hyperextensible skin. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse (MVP), a structural defect of the mitral valves due to myxomatous degeneration that leads to the bulging of the leaflets into the left atrium during systole.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department for acute tearing chest pain that radiates to the back. Despite appropriate therapy, the patient dies. Autopsy shows an increase in mucoid extracellular matrix and loss of smooth muscle cell nuclei in the media of large arteries. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasal septum perforation can be seen in patients with a history of repeated nasal inhalation of cocaine. Although repeated cocaine use can cause acute aortic dissection in a young patient (particularly in those with underlying hypertension), it would not result in histopathologic changes of cystic medial degeneration, as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Inferonasal (down and inward) lens dislocation can occur in patients with underlying homocystinuria. These patients typically have a marfanoid habitus and an increased risk of developing coronary artery disease and stroke because hyperhomocysteinemia induces atherosclerosis and a hypercoagulable state. They do not have an increased risk of developing an aortic dissection or cystic medial degeneration of the large arteries.

C) INCORRECT:

Pes cavus with hammer toes is a characteristic finding in Friedreich ataxia. Although many patients with this condition die at a young age due to cardiovascular complications, the major cause of death is often heart failure resulting from underlying secondary hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not aortic dissection.
Image Description:

There is extension of the distal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the middle digit of the left foot.

D) INCORRECT:

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease increases the risk of developing cerebral berry aneurysms. It does not directly affect the aorta or predispose to aortic dissection. Cardiovascular complications of ADPKD include mitral valve prolapse, left ventricular hypertrophy (typically asymptomatic), and hypertension (which can increase the risk of developing an aortic dissection). Hypertension would not cause the histopathologic changes of cystic medial degeneration seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Deformity of the chest wall (pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum) is a common finding in patients with Marfan syndrome. This condition is strongly associated with aortic pathology, including aortic dissection (as seen in this patient), aortic valve regurgitation, aortic aneurysm, and aortic root dilation. Marfan syndrome is caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, which encodes an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that forms a supportive sheath around elastin. Defects in fibrillin-1 make elastin fibers vulnerable to fragmentation and predispose to mucoid extracellular matrix accumulation, medial fibrosis, and loss of smooth muscle cell nuclei.

Patients with Marfan syndrome classically have marfanoid habitus, joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, skin hyperelasticity, and superotemporal lens subluxation.

F) INCORRECT:

Condylomata lata are characteristic of secondary syphilis, not Marfan syndrome. In addition to condylomata lata, aortic involvement is possible in advanced syphilitic disease but typically does not arise until the final stage (tertiary syphilis) and would be an unlikely finding in this young patient. Furthermore, histopathologic findings of affected arteries in tertiary syphilis show degeneration of the vasa vasorum and vascular wall atrophy (not cystic medial degeneration, as seen in this patient).
Image Description:

Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.

Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.
questions.hint: Acute tearing chest pain with radiation to the back is consistent with aortic dissection, a life-threatening condition. Mucoid extracellular matrix accumulation and loss of smooth muscle cell nuclei from cystic medial degeneration of the large arteries predisposes to aortic dissection, and, in young patients, is indicative of connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective laminin can cause junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in laminin.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective type III collagen is the cause of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents primarily with cardiovascular manifestations. These include heart valve defects (especially mitral valve prolapse), aneurysms or dissections of large arteries (e.g., aortic, iliac), and berry aneurysms of cerebral arteries. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type III collagen.

C) CORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, which encodes fibrillin, an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that forms a supportive sheath around elastin. Abnormal elastin production leads to defective connective tissue and excessive growth factor release. Further features of Marfan syndrome include vascular abnormalities (e.g., aortic aneurysm or dissection).

D) INCORRECT:

Defective type I collagen is the cause of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). Patients with OI can present with joint hypermobility, as seen in this patient, but do not develop lens subluxation, high-arched palate, tall stature, or arachnodactyly. Moreover, patients with OI typically have a history of multiple fractures in the setting of minimal trauma along with blue sclerae and hearing loss. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type I collagen.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective keratin can cause epidermolysis bullosa simplex, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in keratin.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of Marfan syndrome (i.e., tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, joint hypermobility, and superotemporal lens subluxation).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for gradual worsening of her vision. Her father died at 40 years of age. She is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 69 kg (152 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. A standard vision test shows severe myopia. Genetic analysis shows an FBN1 gene mutation on chromosome 15. This patient is at greatest risk of mortality due to which of the following causes?

choices.text: Obstruction of the superior vena cava lumen
Increased pressure in the pulmonary arteries
Intimal tear of the aortic root

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction is an important cause of mortality in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Hereditary HCM can be caused by an autosomal dominant defect in genes responsible for the synthesis of certain sarcomeric proteins (e.g., MYH7, MYBPC3) or by an autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat mutation on the frataxin gene on chromosome 9 (Friedreich ataxia). A mutation in the FBN1 gene is not associated with an increased risk of HCM.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

SVC syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with a mediastinal mass (e.g., lymphoma), Pancoast tumor, or thrombosis due to an indwelling venous catheter. FBN1 gene defects are not associated with an increased risk of SVC syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) can lead to cor pulmonale and right ventricular failure, resulting in death. Genetic causes of PAH include inactivating mutations on the BMPR2 gene on chromosome 2 and connective tissues disease such as systemic sclerosis. However, mutations on the FBN1 gene are not associated with the development of pulmonary hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Eccentric ventricular hypertrophy is the underlying disease process in dilated cardiomyopathy. Genetic causes of dilated cardiomyopathy include certain sarcomeric protein mutations (e.g., TTN gene), Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and hereditary hemochromatosis. Mutations in the FBN1 gene are not associated with an increased risk of dilated cardiomyopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) refers to any tachyarrhythmia that originates above or within the Bundle of His. Causes include a dysfunctional AV node, the presence of an additional electrical pathway (AVNRT), and the presence of an accessory pathway between the atria and ventricles (AVRT, WPW). This patient's condition is not associated with an increased risk of supraventricular tachycardia.

F) CORRECT:

An autosomal dominant defect in the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15 is responsible for Marfan syndrome, which can cause tall stature and myopia, as seen in this patient. Marfan syndrome is associated with cystic medial necrosis of the aorta, which can result in aortic root dissection (e.g., intimal tear), aortic root dilation, and aortic regurgitation. Aortic root disease is the most common cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with Marfan syndrome.

Severe mitral valve prolapse is another common cause of early mortality in patients with Marfan syndrome.
questions.hint: Other abnormal morphometric features of this condition include thoracic wall deformities (e.g., pectus carinatum, pectus excavatum), long extremities, arachnodactyly, subluxation of the lens, and hypermobile joints.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man from Chile comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of upper back pain and difficulty swallowing. He has had pain in his shoulder and knee joints over the past 10 years. He is 190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70.3 kg (155 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg in the right arm and 130/70 mg Hg in the left arm. Physical examination shows a depression in the sternum and a grade 3/6 diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. A CT scan of the chest with contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, which is endemic to South America. This disease can cause dysphagia (due to achalasia) as well as aortic regurgitation (due to dilated cardiomyopathy), which are seen here. However, Chagas disease would not cause pectus excavatum, discordant blood pressure readings, or dilation of the aorta.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune valve damage is the cause of rheumatic heart disease (RHD), which, in the US, is most commonly seen in the immigrant population. RHD can cause a diastolic murmur (due to mitral stenosis), and, rarely, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia megalatriensis due to left atrial enlargement). Rheumatic fever, which is the pathologic precursor to RHD, would also cause pain in large joints such as the knee. However, the joint pain would subside after the acute episode of rheumatic fever, and the diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis would be heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient's murmur is caused by aortic regurgitation, which is not common in RHD. Most importantly, RHD would not cause dilation of the ascending aorta.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA), which predisposes to the formation of ascending aortic aneurysms and can present with back and shoulder pain (due to concurrent polymyalgia rheumatica). However, aortic aneurysm usually occurs late in the course of GCA and the disease virtually never affects patients < 50 years.

Granulomatous inflammation is also seen in Takayasu arteritis, which can lead to chronic arthralgia and discordant blood pressure readings between the upper limbs (due to aortic arch narrowing). Takayasu arteritis can, occasionally, lead to aneurysmal dilation of the ascending aorta with aortic regurgitation and dysphagia, which is seen here. However, the condition typically occurs in Asian women and would usually be associated with other features, such as cutaneous nodules, fever, or night sweats.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic fibroblast proliferation is a pathologic process that occurs in patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc), which can cause dysphagia (due to esophageal dysmotility), chronic arthralgia, and vascular disease. Dysphagia due to SSc usually has a subacute or chronic onset. In addition, arthralgia caused by SSc typically affects the small joints of the hands and feet, and the vasculopathy associated with SSc manifests as Raynaud phenomenon, telangiectasia, or thromboembolic phenomena. Furthermore, SS would not cause pectus excavatum, discordant blood pressure readings, aortic regurgitation, or dilation of the ascending aorta.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital narrowing of the aortic arch (aortic coarctation) can cause discordant blood pressure readings in the limbs. Additionally, a bicuspid aortic valve, which is commonly associated with aortic coarctation, can lead to aortic regurgitation (diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border), which is seen here. However, in the case of aortic coarctation, the discordance is usually between the blood pressure measurements of the upper and lower extremities because the coarctation is typically located just distal to the left subclavian artery. Only in very rare instances would aortic coarctation cause disparate blood pressure measurements in the arms. Furthermore, this condition would not be expected to cause significant dilation of the ascending aorta.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's tall stature and pectus excavatum suggest Marfan syndrome. Individuals with Marfan syndrome have hypermobile joints, which predisposes them to chronic arthralgia as a result of recurrent sprains, bursitis, and/or early-onset osteoarthritis. Cystic medial degeneration, which occurs with aging and in connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, leads to the weakening of the aortic wall and aneurysmal dilation, which are seen here.

G) INCORRECT:

Weakening of the vessel wall due to atheroma formation (atherosclerosis) is the most common cause of an aortic aneurysm, and the marfanoid features in this patient (e.g., tall stature, pectus excavatum) might be due to homocystinuria, which is a risk factor for early-onset atherosclerosis. However, aneurysms due to atherosclerosis typically occur in the thoracic segment and the abdominal segment of the descending aorta. The ascending aortic aneurysm in this patient suggests a different pathologic process.
questions.hint: This axial CT shows an ascending aortic aneurysm, which is often associated with an aortic regurgitation murmur (diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border) caused by dilation of the aortic valve annulus. Dissection of the weakened aneurysmal wall can cause an acute increase in the size of an aneurysm, manifesting with back pain, discordant blood pressure readings in the upper limbs, and difficulty swallowing (dysphagia aortica due to esophageal compression).

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-month history of recurrent bruising that began after he joined his school's basketball team. According to his coach, the bruises appear even after minor contact with other players. His father died suddenly at the age of 38 years due to cerebral hemorrhage. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows translucent skin, multiple large bruises on his stomach and extremities, and varicosis of the lower extremity. There are widened atrophic scars on his elbows and knees. Range of motion of the metacarpophalangeal joints is mildly increased. The patient has prominent eyes, a thin nose and face, and lobeless ears. This patient’s condition puts him at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is associated with several forms of EDS, as well as other genetic connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome. While Marfan syndrome also manifests with joint hypermobility and, in some cases, cerebral hemorrhages at a young age, affected individuals typically have tall stature, long extremities (i.e., an increased arm span-to-height ratio), and arachnodactyly, while this patient is of normal stature. This patient has vascular EDS, which is only rarely is associated with mitral valve prolapse; he is at greater risk for another condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemophilic arthropathy is a chronic joint condition that commonly develops due to repeated hemarthrosis in patients with hemophilia, a genetic bleeding disorder that can also manifest with easy bruising and early-onset cerebral hemorrhage. However, patients with hemophilia typically present with spontaneous or delayed-onset bleeding in multiple locations (e.g., oral mucosa, muscular tissue). Translucent skin and facial abnormalities are not features of hemophilia. This patient has vascular EDS, which is not associated with recurrent hemarthrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperglycemia is commonly seen in patients with Cushing syndrome, which manifests with thin, easily bruisable skin, delayed wound healing, and weight gain. However, Cushing syndrome is also associated with secondary hypertension, moon facies, stretch marks, and muscle weakness. This patient has vEDS, which is not associated with hyperglycemia.

D) CORRECT:

Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vEDS) is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder that is caused by a pathogenic mutation in the COL3A1 gene, which leads to a defective type III procollagen. Patients with this rare and severe type of EDS have a limited life expectancy because of complications such as spontaneous rupture of arteries (e.g., of the aorta, due to dissection or aneurysm) or hollow organs (e.g., colonic rupture). Classical features of other types of EDS (e.g., hypermobile EDS or classical EDS) such as joint hypermobility and skin hyperextensibility are typically absent or less prominent in patients with vEDS. The diagnosis is confirmed with genetic testing.

Other common manifestations of vEDS include spontaneous pneumothorax, clubfoot, arteriovenous fistula, and gingival recession.
Image Description:

Photographs of two patients with the genetic disorder Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are shown. Both patients have prominent eyes, a thin face with sunken cheeks, and small lips (due to reduced subcutaneous fat tissue). The patient on the right has lobeless ears, which are a common sign of this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Conductive hearing loss is a common complication of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), an autosomal-dominant disease that can manifest with easy bruising. However, OI also manifests with short stature, brittle bones, and recurrent bone fractures, while this patient is of normal height and has neither brittle bones nor recurrent fractures. This patient has vEDS, which is not associated with hearing loss.
questions.hint: The combination of extensive bruising, atrophic scars, translucent skin, early-onset varicosis, characteristic facial features (prominent eyes, a thin face, and nose, small lips, and lobeless ears), mild small joint hyperextensibility, and a family history of cerebral hemorrhage before the age of 40 suggests vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vEDS).

questions.text:
An asymptomatic 19-year-old woman who has had several spontaneous pneumothoraces presents for a sports preparticipation evaluation.
She has joint hypermobility, pectus excavatum, and a reduced upper-to-lower body segment ratio.
What additional abnormality might you expect to find on this patient's clinical examination?

choices.text: A midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the right second intercostal space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ocular problems associated with Marfan syndrome include myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and superior lens dislocation. Myopia, not hyperopia, would be more likely due to hypoplastic iris or hypoplastic ciliary muscle.

B) CORRECT:

The presence of pectus excavatum, joint hypermobility, and a reduced upper-to-lower body segment ratio in a patient with a history of spontaneous pneumothoraces is concerning for Marfan syndrome.

Marfan syndrome is caused by a heritable genetic defect of connective tissue, with an autosomal dominant mode of transmission. The defect is found on the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15, which codes for the connective tissue protein fibrillin-1. There are pleiotropic effects caused by the mutation in the fibrillin gene, leading to a wide range of phenotypic features.

Although pulmonary involvement is not considered a major criterion for the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome, many patients have a history of a spontaneous pneumothorax. Patients may also have apical blebs and rib cage abnormalities.

The typical skeletal deformities associated with Marfan syndrome include pectus deformities, arachnodactyly, dolichostenomelia, and thoracolumbar scoliosis.

Key learning point: The presence of pectus excavatum, joint hypermobility, and a reduced upper-to-lower body segment ratio in a patient with a history of spontaneous pneumothoraces is concerning for Marfan syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Within the cardiovascular system, Marfan syndrome can be associated with aortic dilatation, aortic regurgitation, aneurysms, and mitral valve prolapse. A midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the right second intercostal space is suggestive of aortic stenosis, which is not a typical clinical feature of Marfan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is not associated with an increased risk for thyroid nodules.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with Marfan syndrome typically have an arm span-to-height ratio >1.05.

questions.text:
An asymptomatic 17-year-old girl who has had several spontaneous pneumothoraces presents for a sports preparticipation evaluation.
She has joint hypermobility, pectus excavatum, and a reduced upper-to-lower body segment ratio.
What additional abnormality might you expect to find on this patient's clinical examination?

choices.text: A midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the right second intercostal space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with Marfan syndrome typically have an arm span-to-height ratio >1.05.

B) INCORRECT:

C) CORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is caused by a heritable genetic defect of connective tissue, with an autosomal dominant mode of transmission. The defect is found on the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15, which codes for the connective tissue protein fibrillin-1. There are pleiotropic effects caused by the mutation in the fibrillin gene, leading to a wide range of phenotypic features.

D) INCORRECT:

A midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the right second intercostal space is suggestive of aortic stenosis, which is not a typical clinical feature of Marfan syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:
