questions.text:
A 19-year-old male college student presents for a sports preparticipation evaluation. A thorough history is unremarkable.
His vital signs are within normal limits. His height is 200 cm, and his weight is 68 kg, for a BMI of 17 (5th percentile). He has pectus excavatum and pes planus. He is able to wrap his thumb and little finger around the contralateral wrist with overlap, and the distal phalanx of his adducted thumb extends beyond the ulnar border of the palm (figure).
He has a midsystolic click followed by a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the apex. He has normal-sized testicles and pubic hair consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 5.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Noonan syndrome is most commonly an autosomal dominant condition. Pulmonic stenosis is the most commonly associated cardiac issue, and other findings include short stature, easy bruising, strabismus, and sensorineural hearing loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is associated with skin fragility and hyperextensibility, widened atrophic scars, and, rarely, aortic root dilation.

C) INCORRECT:

Stickler syndrome is a constellation of progressive myopia, sensorineural hearing loss, and hypomobility associated with distinct facial features. Affected patients experience accelerated degenerative arthritis with features of osteoarthritis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's tall stature, pectus excavatum, pes planus, and arachnodactyly are suggestive of Marfan syndrome, a multisystem disorder that typically involves the cardiovascular, skeletal, and ocular systems. An additional physical finding suggestive of Marfan syndrome is the thumb sign, where the fully adducted thumb extends beyond the ulnar border of the palm.

The Ghent nosology (https://marfan.org/dx/rules/) is a set of diagnostic criteria with major and minor findings used to identify and diagnose Marfan syndrome.

Patients with Marfan syndrome are at risk for mitral-valve prolapse, which, during cardiac auscultation, manifests as a click followed by a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur. They are also at risk for aortic root dilation with the potential for aortic dissection, a surgical emergency, if the dilation is undiagnosed and progresses.

To help reduce the risk for aortic dissection and sudden death, clinicians should perform an evaluation consisting of electrocardiography, echocardiography, and slit-lamp eye examination for ectopia lentis in the following subsets of patients:

• Those who have a family history of Marfan syndrome
• Males and females who are taller than 183 cm and 178 cm, respectively
• Those who have typical features of Marfan syndrome, such as hypermobility and pectus excavatum

Key learning point: Pectus excavatum, pes planus, arachnodactyly, and a midsystolic click together suggest a diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Poland syndrome is a condition with complete or partial absence of pectoral muscles. Affected individuals may also have missing ribs and other chest-wall structures. They may also have abnormalities of digits, including absent or duplicate digits. There are no associated cardiac abnormalities seen in Poland syndrome, and patients with Poland syndrome do not have the tall stature described in this patient.

questions.text:
A 7-month-old girl is brought in for a well-child visit. Her parents note that she is drooling a great deal. She is currently transitioning to baby foods and continues to breastfeed. She is able to sit with some support, can transfer items from one hand to the other, and babbles.
Her weight, height, and head circumference are tracking along the 30th percentile. Her sclerae are white, she does not have a dysmorphic appearance, and examination of the heart, lungs, and abdomen is normal. She moves all extremities well, with good tone; deep tendon reflexes are noted to be 2+ and symmetric. Her skin is pink and moist with normal nail beds over her hands and feet. There is some fullness over the midline mandibular alveolar ridge.
What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s mandibular fullness?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gingivitis is the most common periodontal finding in older children, but it is uncommon in infants.

B) INCORRECT:

Mucoceles typically manifest on the lower lip mucosa, due to mild oral trauma, and are much less likely to develop on the alveolus.

C) INCORRECT:

Infectious, allergic, and cystic lesions are much less common causes of drooling and oral discomfort in infants and would manifest with visible indications of either a painful lesion or a cystic mass.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious, allergic, and cystic lesions are much less common causes of drooling and oral discomfort in infants and would manifest with visible indications of either a painful lesion or a cystic mass.

E) CORRECT:

The most common reason for drooling and mild-to-moderate oral discomfort in infants is eruption of teeth. As shown in the table below, the mandibular central incisors are the first to erupt, typically at 5 to 8 months of age.

Key learning point: Teething is the most common reason for drooling in infants; the teeth that are expected to be present first in a normal 5- to 8-month-old infant are the mandibular central incisors.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl who is new to your practice presents for a routine well examination. She reports that she has a recent diagnosis of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder and that she is interested in trying out for her school’s basketball team.
On examination, she is noted to have a prominent forehead and to wear eyeglasses for myopia. She is tall for her age (185 cm, >99th percentile) and weighs 50 kg (50th–75th percentile). She has pectus carinatum and mild scoliosis. Her lungs sound clear, but cardiac examination reveals a diastolic murmur that is graded 2 on a scale of 1 to 4. Her joints appear to have increased laxity, and she is able to adduct her entire thumb beyond the ulnar border of the palm. Her feet appear flat.
An echocardiogram shows a dilated aorta, measuring 3.9 cm at the sinuses of Valsalva (z score, 3.22), mitral valve prolapse, and mild aortic regurgitation.
Which one of the following next steps in management is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Discussion of the benefits of stimulant medications for attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder
Genetic testing to check for possible deletion of the elastin gene
Restriction from competitive and contact sports

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stimulant medications are contraindicated in patients with Marfan syndrome with cardiac involvement and should therefore not be prescribed to manage this patient’s attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiograms should be performed annually, rather than every 2 years, in patients with Marfan syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing is indicated to help make the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome, but the genetic mutation seen in Marfan syndrome is in the FBN1 (fibrillin) gene, not the elastin gene. Deletion of the elastin gene, found on chromosome 7, causes Williams syndrome, a genetic disorder associated with arteriopathy, peripheral pulmonary stenosis, supravalvar aortic stenosis, and distinctive facial features that distinguish it from Marfan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient’s aortic dilation, although concerning and important to follow, is 3.9 cm and does not meet the threshold (≥5 cm) for immediate surgical intervention.

E) CORRECT:

Many of this patient’s physical examination findings — including dolichocephaly, pectus malformation, positive thumb sign (in which the entire distal phalanx extends beyond the ulnar border of a clenched fist), flat feet, tall stature, and myopia — are concerning for Marfan syndrome. Further evaluation with an echocardiogram showed mitral valve prolapse and aortic root dilation (z score, >2.0), which further reinforces the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome. Other findings that are used to diagnose this syndrome include ectopia lentis, positive genetic testing for an FBN1 (fibrillin) gene mutation, and a relevant family history. The 2010 Ghent criteria, which guide diagnosis and recognition of Marfan syndrome, include many of the aforementioned phenotypic criteria. Detailed scoring and evaluation should be performed by an experienced specialist.

Cardiac complications of Marfan syndrome are common and include dilated aortic root; aortic regurgitation; mitral valve prolapse with and without regurgitation; heart failure related to aortic regurgitation, mitral regurgitation, or both; and, most deadly, acute aortic dissection and rupture. Patients with Marfan syndrome should be followed closely with imaging, including yearly echocardiograms to detect progressive aortic dilation and regurgitation. CT or MRI studies are often performed to evaluate the entire length of the aorta. Surgery is indicated for patients with an absolute aortic root diameter of ≥5 cm, a rapidly enlarging ascending aorta, or progressive aortic regurgitation. Patients with Marfan syndrome and a dilated aortic root should be restricted from competitive sports, contact sports, and isometric exercise — but regular light activity should be encouraged.

Given the presence of ascending aortic dilation in this patient, she should be restricted from competitive and contact sports. Furthermore, female patients with Marfan syndrome should be counseled by a cardiologist about reproductive risks, including the risk of aortic dissection during pregnancy and the risk of uterine rupture at delivery. Contraceptive options should be offered and discussed early.

Key learning point: Patients with Marfan syndrome and aortic dilation with aortic regurgitation are at risk for aortic dissection.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents for a new patient visit with daily knee and ankle pain that is provoked by activity and has been worsening during the past year. Recently, the pain has been interfering with her ability to participate in soccer, and she also notes that her knees occasionally feel like they are “popping out of place” when she is running.
She was evaluated by orthopedics about one year ago after repeated ankle sprains and was told she had “loose” ankle joints that predisposed her to sprains; at the time, she was advised to do ankle strengthening exercises. One month ago, she was evaluated in urgent care where radiographs of her ankles and knees were unremarkable. She was advised to take ibuprofen on an as-needed basis, which she has been doing before soccer with some improvement in symptoms. She has a history of eczema but no other significant medical history.
She appears nourished and well. She has no evidence of effusions, limitations in motion, or joint tenderness. Her examination is notable for hyperextensibility of the elbows beyond 10 degrees, hyperextensibility of the knees beyond 10 degrees, and an ability to place her palms on the floor with flexion at the waist and knees fully extended. She can also passively dorsiflex her fifth fingers more than 90 degrees. She is unable to appose her thumbs to the flexor aspect of the forearm. The remainder of her examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following family histories should prompt further genetic workup for this patient?

choices.text: First-degree relative with inflammatory bowel disease
First-degree relative with early-onset aortic aneurysm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A history of a first-degree relative with psoriasis or inflammatory bowel disease is important to note in patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), as this history could change the patient’s JIA classification and help predict the disease course and the patient’s response to certain medications. However, the evaluation and risk stratification of a patient with hypermobility is not changed by a positive family history of either of these conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Juvenile fibromyalgia (amplified musculoskeletal pain syndrome) is an important noninflammatory cause of diffuse body pain. Although no genetic link has been found to suggest familial inheritance, it is often seen in children of adults with fibromyalgia, and a positive family history may raise suspicion of this diagnosis in the setting of an otherwise reassuring examination. If juvenile fibromyalgia were suspected, genetic evaluation would not be helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

A history of a first-degree relative with psoriasis or inflammatory bowel disease is important to note in patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), as this history could change the patient’s JIA classification and help predict the disease course and the patient’s response to certain medications. However, the evaluation and risk stratification of a patient with hypermobility is not changed by a positive family history of either of these conditions.

D) INCORRECT:

Although ocular complications are common in a variety of rheumatologic diagnoses, uveitis and scleritis are not associated with EDS and would not change evaluation. A history of a first-degree relative with ocular inflammation should raise concern for a diagnosis of juvenile spondyloarthritis in a child with arthritis or enthesitis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s pain is due to hypermobility-associated arthralgias, as evidenced by her diffuse joint hypermobility and lack of other worrisome signs on joint examination. Hypermobility can be easy to miss on examination if it is not specifically sought out.

Most hypermobility-associated arthralgias are caused by repetitive overextension of the hypermobile joints, but they can also be specifically related to repeated dislocations. Although there can be transient swelling of affected joints, the swelling should not persist, and there should not be any signs of true arthritis, such as effusions, limitations in range of motion, or tenderness on palpation or with passive movement of the joints.

Hypermobility can be measured by the Beighton Scoring System, which takes the following factors into account (maximum score, 9):

• Passive dorsiflexion or hyperextension of the fifth metacarpophalangeal joint beyond 90 degrees (1 point for each pinky finger)
• Passive apposition of the thumb to the flexor aspect of the forearm (1 point for each thumb)
• Passive hyperextension of the elbow beyond 10 degrees (1 point for each elbow)
• Passive hyperextension of the knee beyond 10 degrees (1 point for each knee)
• Active forward flexion of the trunk with the knees fully extended so that the palms of the hands rest flat on the floor (1 point)

Although there is no universally agreed-upon threshold for diagnosing benign juvenile hypermobility syndrome, many clinicians use a Beighton score of ≥5 as a sign of generalized hypermobility in adolescents. This patient has a score of 7 based on her examination.

Although benign hypermobility is relatively common, a careful examination and history are needed because some forms of inherited hypermobility syndromes are associated with more severe sequalae and therefore warrant further evaluation. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is the term used for a group of rare disorders that cause hypermobility and associated physical findings due to genetic mutations in the collagen gene. The most serious consequence of this syndrome is spontaneous vascular rupture, which most commonly manifests as early-onset aortic or brain aneurysms.

In general, EDS should be suspected when a patient presents with characteristic joint hypermobility, recurrent joint dislocations, and characteristic findings on skin examination, including fragile skin, abnormal wound healing with widened atrophic scars (“cigarette-paper scars”), skin hyperextensibility, increased bruisability, and varicosities. If a patient with hypermobility has any of these additional findings on examination or any family history consistent with EDS, they should be evaluated by a geneticist. Thus, a family history of early-onset aortic aneurysm should prompt a genetic evaluation for this patient.

Key learning point: For a patient with joint pain and generalized hypermobility, a positive family history of early-onset aneurysms would warrant additional evaluation for Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy with no significant medical history presents for his annual well-child check. He notes difficulty seeing the board at school, which has gotten worse throughout the school year. He has no other complaints.
Visual acuity testing reveals 20/80 vision bilaterally. His examination is notable for a height of 185 cm (95th percentile), an arm span of 190 cm, a high-arched hard palate, pectus excavatum, joint hypermobility (with the exception of his elbows, which only extend to 170 degrees), and long, slim fingers.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely reason for his poor vision?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has Marfan syndrome, which is an autosomal dominant connective-tissue disorder that causes musculoskeletal, cardiac, and ocular abnormalities. It is caused by mutations in the fibrillin-1 protein.

Ectopia lentis (dislocation of the ocular lens) occurs in about 60% of patients with Marfan syndrome. Although it is not unique to this syndrome, it should always prompt consideration of the diagnosis. Other diseases in which it can occur include homocystinuria, Weill-Marchesani syndrome, and familial ectopia lentis. Marfan syndrome tends to cause a superior dislocation of the lens, whereas homocystinuria more commonly causes an inferior or nasal dislocation.

Musculoskeletal manifestations are typically the most recognizable physical abnormality of Marfan syndrome. Disproportionate overgrowth of the long bones often occurs first and results in tall height, with arm span greater than height. Patients may also have arachnodactyly (overgrowth of the fingers) and pectus excavatum or carinatum. Other musculoskeletal findings include joint laxity, pes planus, scoliosis, a high-arched hard palate, and dental crowding.

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan syndrome include aortic dissection and aneurysm as well as valvular disease, typically mitral and aortic. Patients should undergo annual cardiac evaluation and be counseled to avoid competitive athletics because of risk for sudden death.

Individuals with Marfan syndrome are also at risk for spontaneous pneumothorax.

Key learning point: Individuals with Marfan syndrome are at risk for ectopia lentis (dislocation of the lens of the eye), usually superiorly.

B) INCORRECT:

Blue sclerae are typically seen in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) or in osteogenesis imperfecta, not Marfan syndrome. Patients with EDS can have joint hypermobility and vascular involvement, but the constellation of findings in this patient is more consistent with Marfan syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Ocular abnormalities associated with Marfan syndrome include myopia (as opposed to hyperopia, which is seen in syndromes associated with short eyes and/or flat corneas), decreased miosis secondary to hypoplastic iris or ciliary muscles, increased globe length, retinal detachment, cataracts, and glaucoma. Regular ophthalmologic evaluation with slit-lamp examination should be part of routine medical care.

D) INCORRECT:

Uveitis is seen in a variety of inflammatory diseases but not in Marfan syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Uveitis is seen in a variety of inflammatory diseases but not in Marfan syndrome.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his mother for increasing episodes of palpitations and occasional dizziness. His father passed away suddenly at the age of 45. His height is 195 cm, and his arm span is 208 cm. He has elongated fingers, a high-arched palate, and mild pectus excavatum. Cardiac auscultation reveals a mid-systolic click best heard at the apex. An ocular exam shows dislocation of the right lens (see report).

Blood pressure
120/80 mm Hg

Chest X-ray: Slight widening of the mediastinum; no acute abnormalities
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Homocystinuria can present with marfanoid features and lens dislocation, typically inferonasal. However, it often involves thromboembolic events and cognitive impairments, which are not mentioned. The mid-systolic click and family history of sudden cardiac death suggest a connective tissue disorder rather than a metabolic defect.

B) INCORRECT:

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is characterized by joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility, which are absent here. The patient's features, including lens dislocation and cardiovascular findings, align more with fibrillin defects seen in Marfan syndrome rather than the collagen abnormalities of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Klinefelter syndrome, a 47,XXY chromosomal disorder, is associated with tall stature but typically presents with hypogonadism, gynecomastia, and infertility, which are not noted here. The patient's connective tissue abnormalities and lens dislocation suggest a different genetic disorder, such as Marfan syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Marfan syndrome manifests with connective tissue abnormalities due to mutations in the FBN1 gene, affecting fibrillin-1. The patient exhibits classic features such as tall stature with an arm span exceeding height, arachnodactyly, high-arched palate, and pectus excavatum. Ocular involvement includes lens dislocation, a hallmark of Marfan syndrome. The mid-systolic click suggests mitral valve prolapse, common in this condition due to myxomatous degeneration. The family history of sudden cardiac death and mediastinal widening on imaging further support the diagnosis, highlighting the systemic impact of the disorder.

Key learning point: Marfan Syndrome is characterized by tall stature, skeletal abnormalities, and cardiovascular issues such as mitral valve prolapse and aortic dilatation.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female college student comes to the physician for a sudden loss of visual acuity of her right eye. She noticed that she was unable to read the time on the alarm clock when she woke up in the morning. When she closes her right eye, she is able to see sharply. When she closes her left eye, she has blurry double vision. She does not recall trauma to her eye but has been working long nights on her honors thesis. She has a history of occasional knee luxation. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall, and weighs 62 kg (136 lbs); her BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals:

Positive Adam forward bend test
Increased patellar range of motion
Slender and long fingers
Loss of the medial longitudinal arch of the feet

Ocular examination shows upward temporal subluxation of her right lens. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Ehlers-Danlos syndrome also manifests with joint laxity and arachnodactyly, this woman's disproportionately tall stature and ocular findings suggest another diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2B (MEN2B) often causes a marfanoid habitus with ocular complications, as seen in this patient. However, the ocular complications are due to neuromas and do not involve the lens. Additionally, this patient does not have any signs of other complications of MEN2B, such as pheochromocytoma, oral mucosal neuromas, or thyroid cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Sturge-Weber syndrome may present with ocular complications, the most common being early-onset glaucoma, not lens subluxation. Additionally, characteristic dermatologic findings include a “port-wine stain”.

D) CORRECT:

Marfan syndrome may result in superotemporal lens subluxation due to incompetent zonular fibers and structural abnormalities of the lens capsule. The upward and temporal direction is a relatively specific finding that can help distinguish Marfan syndrome from other causes of lens subluxation. Additionally, her clinical picture (tall stature, arachnodactyly, and recurrent knee luxation) is typical for patients with this condition. This patient requires a thorough cardiac examination, as patients with Marfan syndrome often have cardiovascular complications (e.g., aortic regurgitation and/or aortic dissection).

High-velocity low-amplitude techniques are contraindicated in patients with Marfan syndrome due to joint hypermobility and the increased risk of dislocation.

E) INCORRECT:

Homocystinuria often has a similar clinical presentation to Marfanoid habitus and lens subluxation. However, lens subluxation is typically downward and inward in a patient with homocystinuria, as opposed to the upward and outward direction found in this woman. Additionally, patients with homocystinuria usually have an intellectual disability, megaloblastic anemia, and thromboembolic events or premature atherosclerosis.
questions.hint: This tall woman presents with lens subluxation, arachnodactyly, scoliosis, pes planus, and joint hypermobility, which raise suspicion for a hereditary connective tissue disorder.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents with a 2-month history of blurry vision. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination reveals:

Joint hypermobility
High-arched palate
Abnormally long, slender fingers and toes

T4–T6 neutral, sidebent right, rotated left
Hypertonicity of the upper thoracic paraspinal musculature

Slit lamp examination reveals superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Defective type I collagen is the cause of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). Patients with OI can present with joint hypermobility, as seen in this patient, but do not develop lens subluxation, high-arched palate, tall stature, or arachnodactyly. Moreover, patients with OI typically have a history of multiple fractures in the setting of minimal trauma along with blue sclerae and hearing loss. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type I collagen.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective type III collagen is the cause of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents primarily with cardiovascular manifestations. These include heart valve defects (especially mitral valve prolapse), aneurysms or dissections of large arteries (e.g., aortic, iliac), and berry aneurysms of cerebral arteries. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type III collagen.

C) CORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, which encodes fibrillin, an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that forms a supportive sheath around elastin. Abnormal elastin production leads to defective connective tissue and excessive growth factor release. Further features of Marfan syndrome include vascular abnormalities (e.g., aortic aneurysm or dissection).

D) INCORRECT:

Defective laminin can cause junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in laminin.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective keratin can cause epidermolysis bullosa simplex, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in keratin.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of Marfan syndrome (i.e., tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, joint hypermobility, superotemporal lens subluxation, and a type 1 somatic dysfunction of the thoracic spine that should raise concern for scoliosis).

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the ED after twisting her left ankle while descending stairs. She reports mild pain and no other injuries. Her medical history scoliosis diagnosed in early adolescence (shown in photograph), which has been stable for 5 years, a retinal detachment 2 years ago, and hypermobility. Cardiac auscultation reveals a soft early diastolic murmur at the left sternal border. Ankle radiograph shows no fracture. Which of the following serious complications is this patient most at risk for?

choices.text: Progressive restrictive lung disease from severe thoracic scoliosis
Ascending aortic aneurysm with risk of dissection
Mitral valve stenosis with left atrial enlargement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe scoliosis can cause restrictive ventilatory impairment and reduced exercise tolerance, but this complication develops gradually and the patient's scoliosis is stable. Her body shape, hypermobility, previous retinal detachment, and scoliosis suggest an underlying condition that puts her at elevated risk of other complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Uterine rupture occurs in vascular Ehlers–Danlos syndrome (type IV), a distinct connective tissue disorder caused by type III collagen deficiency. In Marfan syndrome, which this patient has multiple features of, pregnancy-related mortality is due to aortic root dilation and dissection, not uterine rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's body shape, past history of scoliosis and retinal detachment, and cardiac findings suggest Marfan syndrome. Pulmonary hypertension is seen in disorders such as systemic sclerosis or lupus, not Marfan syndrome. The most common pulmonary complication in Marfan is spontaneous pneumothorax from apical blebs, not vascular remodeling.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient’s marfanoid habitus, skeletal deformities, and history of retinal detachment are characteristic of Marfan syndrome. The early diastolic murmur indicates aortic root dilation, a hallmark cardiovascular manifestation of the disorder. Progressive dilation predisposes to aortic aneurysm, aortic regurgitation, and acute dissection; the principal causes of morbidity and premature death in affected patients. In the ED, recognition of these features should prompt referral to cardiology and medical genetics for diagnostic confirmation, echocardiographic assessment of the aortic root, and strict blood pressure control with beta-blockade to reduce aortic wall stress.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse may occur in Marfan syndrome, which this patient has multiple features of, but mitral valve stenosis is not typical.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of easy bruising. He has met all developmental milestones. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows velvety, fragile skin that can be stretched further than normal and multiple ecchymoses. Joint range of motion is increased. A defect in which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

α-Collagen triple helix formation is disrupted in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta. Though this condition can manifest with easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility, most patients also have a history of numerous fractures with minimal trauma. Other common manifestations include blue sclerae, hearing loss, and dental abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

α1-Antitrypsin production by the liver is reduced in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency. In severe cases, this condition can manifest with early liver dysfunction (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis) and panacinar emphysema. This condition does not cause easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrillin-1 glycoprotein production is disrupted in patients with Marfan syndrome, which can also cause skin hyperelasticity and joint hypermobility. However, this patient lacks other characteristic manifestations of Marfan syndrome, including tall and slender stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, pectus excavatum, and lens dislocation. Moreover, Marfan syndrome does not cause easy bruising.

D) INCORRECT:

Proline and lysine hydroxylation is impaired in patients with scurvy because vitamin C is a necessary cofactor in this process. Though this condition can manifest with easy bruising, patients also typically have signs and symptoms of malnutrition such as poor wound healing and an impaired immune response. This condition does not cause skin hyperelasticity or joint hypermobility.

E) CORRECT:

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome has several subtypes, all of which share the underlying mechanism of defective collagen synthesis and/or processing. In patients with impaired lysine-hydroxylysine cross-linking of tropocollagen (e.g., due to enzyme deficiencies), stable collagen fibrils cannot be formed, leading to the characteristic presentation seen in this patient. Defects in type III collagen and type V collagen can also cause this condition.

Problems with collagen cross-linking are also seen in Menkes disease due to decreased activity of lysyl oxidase.
Image Description:

Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.
questions.hint: This boy has findings consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which typically manifests with easy bruising, skin hyperelasticity, and joint hypermobility.
